{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3338760,"name":"Waleed Altobji","username":"wal","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/w/d6d6ee/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-20T19:14:11.455Z","cooked":"

Recently I was looking into how to use the limelight camera for object detection for the game pieces in this years FRC. Do we need any other hardware other than the limelight itself in order to use it for object detection? If so, any recommendations / tutorials?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2024-03-20T19:14:11.455Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":676,"reads":193,"readers_count":192,"score":3418.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":459481,"topic_slug":"limelight-game-piece-detection-help","display_username":"Waleed Altobji","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":65271,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/limelight-game-piece-detection-help/459481/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3338769,"name":"Jainish Patel","username":"JaiCodes","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jaicodes/{size}/203987_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-20T19:20:11.299Z","cooked":"

You need a google coral for neural networks running on the limelight. It processes the necessary calculations for the model and not using one won’t work since the raspberry pi in the limelight is not fast enough to do the calculations.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2024-03-20T19:36:42.291Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":193,"readers_count":192,"score":53.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":459481,"topic_slug":"limelight-game-piece-detection-help","display_username":"Jainish Patel","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":54172,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"4065 NOP | Programming Lead"},"post_url":"/t/limelight-game-piece-detection-help/459481/2","custom_user_title":"4065 NOP | Programming Lead","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3338775,"name":"Jackson Elia","username":"Traptricker","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/traptricker/{size}/215403_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-20T19:23:38.584Z","cooked":"

If you want to use a limelight, you’re going to need a limelight 3 or 3g and a google coral. If you don’t have the funds for that, you can put in a little more work and get a usb camera and a raspberry pi. I wrote a Python script to detect notes using opencv. Note Detection with OpenCV

Could we use the raspberry PI with the limelight or does the limelight need the google coral specifically?

Just a quick note on this, the 3G can’t do game piece detection. It’s just the 3 with a google coral that can

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2024-03-20T21:38:09.148Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":139,"readers_count":138,"score":32.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":459481,"topic_slug":"limelight-game-piece-detection-help","display_username":"Cecilia","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":53032,"username":"Traptricker","name":"Jackson Elia","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/traptricker/{size}/215403_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":61038,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/limelight-game-piece-detection-help/459481/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3338991,"name":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/slab-mr.thomas/{size}/182153_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-20T22:26:44.413Z","cooked":"
Traptricker:

Note Detection with OpenCV

My guess is the OpenCV program will easily run on a robRIO V2 (and easily converted to Java if need be). There are vision examples in the VSCode. We used to do more than this processing on the original roboRIO which is much slower. Of course that was before Command-Based which uses significant CPU.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2024-03-20T22:26:44.413Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":131,"readers_count":130,"score":51.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":459481,"topic_slug":"limelight-game-piece-detection-help","display_username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24594,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/limelight-game-piece-detection-help/459481/6","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3340047,"name":"Jackson Elia","username":"Traptricker","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/traptricker/{size}/215403_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-21T20:46:49.324Z","cooked":"

I think you’re probably right. My team just used a pi and network tables rather than doing it on the rio, but OpenCV is not very demanding, so you could do it on the rio.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2024-03-21T20:46:49.324Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":10,"reads":117,"readers_count":116,"score":73.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":459481,"topic_slug":"limelight-game-piece-detection-help","display_username":"Jackson Elia","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":24594,"username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","name":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/slab-mr.thomas/{size}/182153_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53032,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"4829 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/limelight-game-piece-detection-help/459481/7","custom_user_title":"4829 Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3340233,"name":"EricRehder","username":"EricRehder","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/e/7ab992/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-22T00:20:53.379Z","cooked":"

Limelight has built in functions to easily identify objects by color, size, aspect ratio, etc. In their documentation look for color filtering-thresholding wands-hue. In minutes you can have limelight identifying orange objects in the field of view. That’s probably sufficient, but you can filter a bit more with the Contour Filtering and Sorting section to sort them for large/small, fat/skinny, etc.

No Coral, No AI, needed to go find the orange thing on a background of grey carpet with blue and red bumpers running around. Easy.

The software release 2024.1 on 2/24/24 has a section Note Detector. I’m not sure what that is but there may be some sorting specific to a hollow ring.

The AI stuff comes in if you have a variety of similar objects that the above controls can’t effectively sort out. Or if you had multiple rings on top of each other. Then AI has much more advanced capability to recognize the intended object. But far more complex, expensive, and I would expect slower.

You can use limelight 2 and 2+ can use the google coral for note detection.
